I'm only 5 hours in so far, but i'm loving the game. Feels like playing an RTS version of Arma 3. Im a big fan of large scale RTS games from Total war to Starcraft and this game scratches the modern combat itch that I didn't even know I had. 
It's easy to say it's not bringing anything new to the table, that you can get the same type of gameplay from any of the Command & Conquer games, even the earlier games made by this same developer, but this game has something that none of the others have had so far; Atmosphere. You put your 'good' gaming headphones on, crank the volume to 50%, and you're instantly immersed in the sounds, sights, and anxiety of modern warfare. Sometimes i'll play a skirmish with AI on my team just to zoom in and follow individual units as they fight across the battlefields. It makes me feel like a kid again, playing with my little plastic army men. Can't put a price on nostalgia and atmosphere..
10/10 buy it.

I tanked the settings as low as they'd go and then cranked them as high as they'd go....and the game is always pretty. If you are on the borderline with specs, it will still be pretty even if you have to turn off all the bells and whistles. If you ARE able to crank it up, though, it's basically like watching a Cold War documentary, as historical accuracy is also a thing in this gem. 

So yea, basically, in short: I got it on sale, but it's worth it at full price. I can tell this is one of those games you can sink hundreds of hours in and always go back for more. To whit: It has mod support, including Steam Workshop integration. And as you all know, a game with a lively mod community = countless hours of blissful gaming.

The M60 is a U.S. second-generation main battle tank that entered service around 1960 as an evolution of the M48 Patton. It kept the general Patton layout but introduced a new wedge-shaped hull, diesel engine, and‚Äîcrucially‚Äîa 105 mm M68 gun derived from the British L7, giving it a major firepower boost over earlier American tanks. Designed by Chrysler and built in large numbers (over 15,000 of all variants), it became the primary U.S. MBT throughout much of the Cold War before the M1 Abrams took over. 


The M60 family went through several key variants. The M60A1 added a new longer ‚Äúneedle-nose‚Äù turret with thicker armor, improving survivability. The oddball M60A2 ‚ÄúStarship‚Äù tried to field a 152 mm gun/launcher capable of firing Shillelagh missiles, but it proved complex and unreliable. The definitive model was the M60A3, which folded in reliability upgrades, better fire control, laser rangefinders, and thermal sights, keeping the basic 105 mm gun but giving the tank far better hit probability and night-fighting capability. 


In terms of performance, an M60A3 weighs roughly 54‚Äì55 short tons, uses a 750 hp AVDS-1790 diesel, and tops out at about 30 mph on roads with a range around 300 mi. It has a four-man crew (commander, gunner, loader, driver) and typical secondary armament of a .50 cal machine gun plus a 7.62 mm coax. Although retired from U.S. frontline service by the late 1990s, M60s have seen combat with many operators‚Äîfrom the Yom Kippur War to Operation Desert Storm and even more recent Middle Eastern conflicts‚Äîoften in upgraded forms with added armor and modern optics to keep an old but solid hull relevant.

**NOTE** SOUTHAG as of today, the seventh of October 2025, has been released. Good on the team for buckling down and finally getting it out, and I am editing the review with this note at the beginning to reflect that, whilst the situation regarding SOUTHAG itself has now resolved, the deeper problem(s) that it revealed in how the WARNO team communicates with the playerbase remain. However I do hope that in time there will be a point where this review will prove to be able to be at worst, removed, and at best, replaced with a positive review. **END NOTE**


First and foremost, I wish to be clear: WARNO itself is a solid(ish) to good stand-alone Wargame RTS, and is an -OUTSTANDING- successor to the Wargame series. With that said it is plagued by two major factors that, in my opinion, cause it to suffer severely: 

1) A severe lack of sticking to timelines in regards to DLC content promised both pre-release and post launch.

2) The inability to be clear, concise, and frank with the playerbase when it comes to their timelines for aforementioned delays.

This is something that is most offensive and downright unacceptable in their last section of the WARNO - Expansion Pass DLC; SOUTHAG. 

The Release Schedule for the Expansion Pass was quite straightforward, Nemesis 1 was to Release in Q3 of 2024, Nemesis 2 and NORTHAG were to both release Q4 2024, and SOUTHAG was to release Q2 of 2025. You could purchase the Expansion Pass to save 20% on all four items. Nemesis 1 released quite literally the 1st day of Q3 2024, one couldn't ask for a better start and it was received very well; Nemesis 2 was released Oct. 30th which, whilst the tail end of October, is still the first month in Q4, and by far acceptable and a good pace. Rounding out the year was NORTHAG releasing Dec. 17th, easily making it in before Christmas and the end of Q4, which left one to simply wait until April for Q2 to begin and SOUTHAG to appear....right? 

We are now, at the time of writing this (20:33 UTC -4) two days away from the start of Q4 of 2025. SOUTHAG is in early access for only those who have purchased the Expansion Pass (a concept I dislike, but understand from the situation the developers are in), however what I find rather angering is the following: The Expansion Pass costs 47.99 USD to purchase, more than the entire game, and I personally own Nemesis 1, 2, and NORTHAG! Yet the values of the three DLC's (34.97 USD) is not subtracted from the Expansion Pass. The closest thing to a 'discount' I get is if I purchase WARNO - Gold Edition because I have the Digital Guides and WARNO base game already so I get a 20% off discount bringing it down to 38.39 USD. 

Lads, I know ya'll are in a hard place trying to get this done, but I cannot underscore how frustrating it is to see update after update of "Guys, it's ALMOST here, we SUPER DUPER PROMISE! *smiley face*" whilst either announcing -more DLC-, or showing off assets that the majority of the playerbase cannot use. A phrase my grandfather uses often is "Don't show me the pain, show me the baby", and it is applicable here. I understand the wish to update us as a community, but perhaps don't tell us the fifth time that SOUTHAG is -almost ready- for release, and only say so when you have a -date- for the release. For goodness sake, don't let Paradox of all people do better DLC policy than you guys, that's just unacceptable. if people own other parts of a bundle/expansion pass, they ought to at-least get -some- form of discount if they are trying to buy the last bit of the pass, especially in a case like this. If you're not buying this SOLELY for the multiplayer, don't bother. The single player AI is almost nonexistent, and the balance is horrible. PACT tanks like the T80 are just better than any tank NATO gets, their better armor and accuracy are irrelevant when they're outranged and miss every shot anyway because they took one or two ATGM shots from PACT tanks pushing up. Almost all PACT infantry come with disposable IFVs (if you don't kill their infantry, they just come back for the next battle) with ATGMs that can kill any NATO vehicle while NATO gets few infantry units with HMG armed transports, let alone full IFVs. They also get wayyyyy to much artillery, and you'll have to spend half your time microing your units away from their bombardments because one of their scouts half the map away revealed your unit for .01 seconds. 

The AI is completely non-reactionary to what you're doing. It won't move units to counter you, it won't react to their position in any way. It'll shove most of its units down one area of the map, scatter ATGM teams and vehicles around the rest and might call in one or two planes per battle. I've had battles where they'll move tanks and IFVs down a road 200 meters behind a unit of my tanks that I know they see because they're currently shooting at other units of theirs, but won't move those vehicles through the forest to kill them. 

All this combined leads to nothing but frustration, because if you try to play the game like how you think you should all of your units, especially tanks, will get ripped to pieces. Try to push 6 tanks across a field? They're killed by ATGMS before they even get close. Want to send infantry through a town? They die because you turned your attention away for 5 seconds and they got artillery'd. Put a ATGM team in a woodline? They die because the AI doesn't need scouts to see them. 

It's a horribly frustrating experience and the only way to succeed is to play /around/ the AI, not against it.

TL;DR: I strongly do not recommend this game. Hopefully it gets better within a couple years, but to me it currently feels like the named-and-shamed method of pushing unfinished content out the door that appears appealing enough to get sales but is ultimately lacking in several critical areas.

Things I don't like:
- Awkwardly straddles the line between realism and arcade. If they want realism there needs to be so much more balancing, polishing, and emphasis on unit behaviors during combat. I think the devs may have backed themselves into an unrealistic mountain of work with how many units, weaponry, and factions they included from the get-go. If they want more arcadey, that doesn't change how much work needs to be done. 
- The balancing and mechanics in the existing game are generally kinda poor or confusing. 
- Units don't feel very different, even the special forces and kitted-out vehicles. How can a unit like Tanya in a decades-old Command & Conquer game totally sell the special forces feel and gameplay but the special forces in this game play almost exactly like basic infantry units by comparison? Overall, there aren't many special abilities that would fit into the realism aspect, either. 
- It's really frustrating when you tell a unit to move/flee but they sit completely still in an open field to fire/return fire like a fish in a bucket. There's moments like this in the game where unit commands feel more like unit suggestions.
- I can't shake the impression that there was a huge emphasis on visual-accuracy of units (uniforms, camos, how weaponry looks, etc.), overall 80's vibes, and period-correct small details (low-quality audio for voice-overs and unit speech-lines as well as how/what they say), but that the meat of the game, from the outset, wasn't addressed as thoroughly as the aesthetics.
- There's purchasable DLC all the time but it seems like the base-game is neglected.
- Most importantly, why does it feel like I have to give this company my social security number and blood type to play online multiplayer? Definitely not hitting any good 80's vibes with that. 

Confuses me in a bad way:
- Air support can't see ground enemies unless another unit has line-of-sight but isn't spotted or dead. You mean to tell me that in 1989 there was no briefing, tech packages, or eyeballs in those pilots? Maybe that's why they fly in circles constantly until they run out of fuel? 
- How do enemy tanks/armor just immediately know where my infantry are barricaded in buildings with pinpoint accuracy? 
- There's a little too much emphasis on certain tanks. planes, etc. over what would have likely been used if the Cold War went hot. I don't see omniscient T-80 tank crews mowing down M1 Abrams.

The good:
- The soundtrack slaps, the 80's feel is the best out of any game I've played (isn't obnoxiously overdone), and the nostalgia deja vu vision wobbles got me a few times. 
- Units look very good.
- Basic controls are not overly complicated or confusing. 
- Sound effects are great.

How do I best sum this all up? Like the rush you feel the first time you call in an A-10 Warthog with bops blaring and vibes on-point, but then it flies in circles and gets blown out of the sky. I really wish I knew beforehand just how surface-deep this all was.

Army General is a big step up from the old Wargame singleplayer campaign and easily the best part of the package. Playing these operations in coop or against friends is genuinely fun. The new multiplayer focused Army General mode finally gives structure and context instead of just throwing you into random matches, and it keeps you busy for many hours.

On top of that, there are quality of life improvements. Menus, UI and general game flow feel smoother and more modern. Compared to its predecessor, the whole game simply plays cleaner and more coherent.

Unfortunately, the division and deck system is also the biggest disappointment. It should not really be called a builder, because you are not truly building a division, you are mostly just choosing a pre made one. Real customization with units that are actually viable in PvP is extremely limited. As a result, the playstyle of each division is basically locked in from the start.

Yes, this design makes it easier to sell more divisions as DLC and to balance them on paper, but it kills the core thing that made Wargame decks so addictive. The fun, sometimes frustrating process of deciding which of five slightly different bombers fits your plan best is simply gone. In practice there is usually one optimal deck layout per division and that is it.

In short: if you want to play Army General together with friends, whether in coop or against each other, the game is absolutely worth a look. If you mainly want loose skirmishes and deep deck building, then Wargame Red Dragon or another title will probably suit you better.

First and foremost, I wish to be clear: WARNO itself is a solid(ish) to good stand-alone Wargame RTS, and is an -OUTSTANDING- successor to the Wargame series. With that said it is plagued by two major factors that, in my opinion, cause it to suffer severely: 

1) A severe lack of sticking to timelines in regards to DLC content promised both pre-release and post launch.

2) The inability to be clear, concise, and frank with the playerbase when it comes to their timelines for aforementioned delays.

This is something that is most offensive and downright unacceptable in their last section of the WARNO - Expansion Pass DLC; SOUTHAG. 

The Release Schedule for the Expansion Pass was quite straightforward, Nemesis 1 was to Release in Q3 of 2024, Nemesis 2 and NORTHAG were to both release Q4 2024, and SOUTHAG was to release Q2 of 2025. You could purchase the Expansion Pass to save 20% on all four items. Nemesis 1 released quite literally the 1st day of Q3 2024, one couldn't ask for a better start and it was received very well; Nemesis 2 was released Oct. 30th which, whilst the tail end of October, is still the first month in Q4, and by far acceptable and a good pace. Rounding out the year was NORTHAG releasing Dec. 17th, easily making it in before Christmas and the end of Q4, which left one to simply wait until April for Q2 to begin and SOUTHAG to appear....right? 

We are now, at the time of writing this (20:33 UTC -4) two days away from the start of Q4 of 2025. SOUTHAG is in early access for only those who have purchased the Expansion Pass (a concept I dislike, but understand from the situation the developers are in), however what I find rather angering is the following: The Expansion Pass costs 47.99 USD to purchase, more than the entire game, and I personally own Nemesis 1, 2, and NORTHAG! Yet the values of the three DLC's (34.97 USD) is not subtracted from the Expansion Pass. The closest thing to a 'discount' I get is if I purchase WARNO - Gold Edition because I have the Digital Guides and WARNO base game already so I get a 20% off discount bringing it down to 38.39 USD. 

Lads, I know ya'll are in a hard place trying to get this done, but I cannot underscore how frustrating it is to see update after update of "Guys, it's ALMOST here, we SUPER DUPER PROMISE! *smiley face*" whilst either announcing -more DLC-, or showing off assets that the majority of the playerbase cannot use. A phrase my grandfather uses often is "Don't show me the pain, show me the baby", and it is applicable here. I understand the wish to update us as a community, but perhaps don't tell us the fifth time that SOUTHAG is -almost ready- for release, and only say so when you have a -date- for the release. For goodness sake, don't let Paradox of all people do better DLC policy than you guys, that's just unacceptable. if people own other parts of a bundle/expansion pass, they ought to at-least get -some- form of discount if they are trying to buy the last bit of the pass, especially in a case like this.
